ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to listen to pop music in an analytical way
I learned how to transcribe vocal melodies with a piano, write sheet music, analyze song form and chord progressions
I learned how to formally evaluate pop songs based on methods we learned in class, and most of them were really fun!
An understanding of elements of pop music composition, especially form and chord progressions. Practice with listening.
I learned how to articulate analysis of popular music, specifically in regards to harmonic analysis which was a main focus of the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great class. Nate Adam is a genius and it's really cool to watch his theory framework be amended right in front of you (I hope there is a textbook one day!). Weekly assignments are low stakes and fun.
Strengths: weekly assignments heavily relate to course teaching. Great music examples. Student work and songs in the homework were brought up in class. Weaknesses: None

the biggest strength of the course is that you're able to connect it to the music that you like so it's very open. the only weakness is that it gets a little awkward and quiet at times, probably because of the seating arrangement
Strengths: fun and very doable assignments. Weaknesses: none

Only thing I'd change is to spend some more time on instrumentation/arrangement and a little less on covers/interpolation. The format of the class where much of the time was spent listening was a real strength. I also like how examples were used spanning so many genres and time periods, from Irving Berlin to Carly Rae Jepsen . . . and more Carly Rae Jepsen . . . and even more Carly Rae Jepsen.
I think the lectures could be more engaging and more intellectually challenging. It was too easy to coast in the class and not put in much work. Requiring more engagement would've made it more fun.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Very enjoyable and the professor is clearly knowledgeable and passionate about pop music and music theory
Yes- it's not too hard but you learn a lot and it's very applicable to everyday music appreciation. Accessible to non music majors.

Would definitely recommend, especially as a lighter 5th class to take if you are interested in how songs are constructed. This course is very much what you make of it, as you can spend as little or as much time as you want on the assignments (which are always really interesting and topically relevant to the lectures). The final project, which is to fully analyze a song of your choice and present on it to the class, is really fun. Professor Adam is super knowledgeable in this space and you will learn stuff that will make you better appreciate the music you listen to.
yes! it would probably be a little helpful to have knowledge of chords and things like that though
Yes, if you like listening to songs that you already like for homework, then take this class.
This is one of those rare rating 5, workload 1 unicorn classes. If you're interested in music or songwriting, this class is basically perfect.
Only if they had a strong interest in this area. I think you really have to have a reason to take it.
